# SoCS 2025: Call for Papers

The 18th International Symposium on Combinatorial Search (SoCS 2025) will be held from **August 12-15, 2025**, at the **University of Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom**. The symposium is co-located with the 31st International Conference on Principles and Practice of Constraint Programming (CP 2025) and the 18th International Conference on Theory and Applications of Satisfiability Testing (SAT 2025).

**Submissions are now closed.**

## Overview

Heuristic search and other forms of combinatorial search and optimization are active research areas in artificial intelligence, robotics, planning, constraint programming, meta-reasoning, navigation, bioinformatics, and other fields. SoCS aims to foster collaboration and idea exchange among researchers in these areas. Submissions presenting real-world applications of heuristic search are particularly encouraged.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include but are not limited to:

*   Adversarial search
*   Analysis of search algorithms
*   Automated synthesis of lower bounds
*   Bidirectional search
*   Bounding and pruning techniques
*   Combinatorial optimization
*   Combinatorial puzzles
*   Continuous problem solving
*   Constraint search
*   Deep learning in heuristics and search
*   External-memory and parallel search
*   Heuristics
*   Incremental and active learning in search
*   Machine learning for or in search algorithms
*   Metareasoning and search
*   Methodology and critiques of current practice
*   Model-based search
*   Multi-agent pathfinding
*   Pathfinding
*   Portfolios of search algorithms
*   Problem compilation
*   Problem solving using search
*   Random vs. systematic search strategy selection
*   Real-life applications
*   Real-time search
*   Reinforcement learning and search
*   Search in goal-directed problem solving
*   Search space discretization for continuous state-space problems
*   Search-based diagnosis
*   Search in boolean satisfiability
*   Search in machine learning and big data analytics
*   Search methods in robotics
*   Self-configuring and self-tuning algorithms
*   Symmetry handling
*   Time, memory, and solution quality trade-offs

## Types of Submissions

*   **Technical papers:** Original long (up to 8 pages plus up to one page of references) and short (up to 4 pages plus up to one page of references) papers reporting substantial original research.
*   **Position papers:** Original long (up to 8 pages plus up to one page of references) and short (up to 4 pages plus up to one page of references) papers discussing ideas and concepts related to heuristic and combinatorial search.
*   **Extended abstracts:** (up to 2 pages, including references) for original work, work-in-progress, or recently published/under-review work.

## Submission Instructions

*   Submissions must be original and not submitted concurrently to a journal or another conference.
*   **Double-blind reviewing** will be provided; submitted papers must omit author names and affiliations (except for specific cases of extended abstracts).
*   The submission process involves registering the paper abstract in EasyChair first, followed by the full paper submission.
*   Supplementary material (video, appendices) may be submitted but must also be anonymized.

## Important Dates (Regular Submissions)

*   **Paper abstract submission deadline:** March 19, 2025 (Closed)
*   **Paper submission deadline:** March 26, 2025 (Closed)
*   **Author response:** May 2-5, 2025 (Past)
*   **Notification:** May 16, 2025
*   **Camera-ready copy:** May 30, 2025

*All deadlines are at 23:59 UTC-12.*

## Awards

*   Best paper award
*   Best student paper award (for eligible papers)

## Registration

*   **Early registration:** until June 30, 2025
*   **Late registration:** closes July 31, 2025

# SOSP 2025: Call for Papers

The 31st ACM Symposium on Operating Systems Principles (SOSP) invites submissions presenting innovative and exciting research related to the design, implementation, analysis, evaluation, and deployment of computer systems software.

## Where and When

*   **Venue:** Lotte Hotel World, Seoul, Republic of Korea
*   **Dates:** Monday to Thursday, October 13 – 16, 2025

## Important Dates

*   **Deadline to register abstracts:** April 10, 2025; 23:59 PT
*   **Submission deadline (no extensions):** April 17, 2025; 23:59 PT
*   **Reviews available for author response:** July 1, 2025
*   **Author response due:** July 3, 2025
*   **Author notification:** July 15, 2025
*   **Camera ready due:** TBD
*   **Workshop/Tutorial Proposals Due:** April 29, 2025
*   **Workshop/Tutorial Notification of Acceptance:** May 4, 2025

## Topics of Interest

SOSP takes a broad view of systems and solicits contributions from many fields of systems practice, including:

*   operating systems
*   file and storage systems
*   distributed systems
*   cloud computing
*   mobile and edge systems
*   secure and reliable systems
*   systems aspects of big data and machine learning
*   embedded and real-time systems
*   virtualization
*   networking as it relates to operating systems
*   management and troubleshooting of complex systems

We also welcome work that explores the interaction of computer systems with related areas such as computer architecture, networking, programming languages, analytics, verification, and databases.

## Submission Criteria

Submissions will be judged on novelty, significance, interest, clarity, relevance, and correctness. A good paper will:

*   Motivate a significant problem;
*   Propose and implement an interesting, compelling solution;
*   Demonstrate the practicality and benefits of the solution;
*   Draw appropriate conclusions;
*   Clearly describe the paper's contributions;
*   Articulate the advances beyond previous work; and
*   Be accessible to the broader systems community.

## Originality and Resubmissions

*   Submissions should contain original, unpublished material. Simultaneous submission of the same work to multiple venues, submission of previously published work, or plagiarism is not allowed.
*   Submissions that extend the authors' previous work are welcome, but authors must explain the differences.
*   Prior or concurrent publication in non-peer-reviewed contexts, like arXiv.org, technical reports, talks, and social media posts, is explicitly permitted.
*   Submitting a paper that was previously submitted to another conference is permitted, provided authors have improved the paper and provide details of revisions.

## Anonymity

SOSP will use **double-blind reviewing**. Please make a good faith attempt to anonymize your submission. Avoid identifying yourself or your institution explicitly or by implication. The first page should use the paper ID assigned during registration. Reference your own past work in the third person.

## Formatting

*   Submissions must be in PDF format.
*   Maximum **12 pages** of technical content (including figures, tables, etc.). Bibliographic references are not included in the page limit.
*   Use A4 or US letter paper size, with text and figures fitting inside a 178 x 229 mm (7 x 9 in) block.
*   Two columns separated by 8 mm (0.33 in) whitespace.
*   10-point font on 12-point leading.
*   Graphs and figures should be readable without magnification, preferably in color but readable in grayscale.
*   All pages should be numbered, and references within the paper should be hyperlinked.
*   Violations of formatting rules will not be considered for publication.
*   Recommended to use the official SIGPLAN LaTeX or MS Word templates from ACM.

## Submission

Papers must be submitted electronically in PDF format via the [HotCRP Submission Site](https://sosp25.hotcrp.com/).

## Questions

Any questions about paper submissions can be emailed to sosp2025@gmail.com.

# Call for Papers - IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP)

The 46th IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP) will be held from **May 12-15, 2025**, at the **Hyatt Regency San Francisco, San Francisco, CA**.

Since 1980, the IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy has been the premier forum for presenting developments in computer security and electronic privacy, and for bringing together researchers and practitioners in the field.

## Topics of Interest

We solicit previously unpublished papers offering novel research contributions in any aspect of security or privacy. Papers may present advances in the theory, design, implementation, analysis, verification, or empirical evaluation and measurement of secure systems. Theoretical papers must make a convincing case for the relevance of their results to practice.

Topics include:

*   Applied cryptography
*   Attacks with novel insights, techniques, or results
*   Authentication, access control, and authorization
*   Blockchains and distributed ledger security
*   Cloud computing security
*   Cyber physical systems security
*   Distributed systems security
*   Economics of security and privacy
*   Embedded systems security
*   Formal methods and verification
*   Hardware security
*   Hate, Harassment, and Online Abuse
*   Human-centered security and privacy
*   Intrusion detection and prevention
*   Machine learning and computer security
*   Malware and unwanted software
*   Network security and measurement
*   Operating systems security
*   Privacy-enhancing technologies, anonymity, and censorship
*   Program and binary analysis
*   Protocol security
*   Security and privacy metrics
*   Security and privacy policies
*   Security architectures
*   Security for at-risk populations
*   Software supply chain security
*   Systems security
*   User studies for security and privacy
*   Web security and privacy
*   Wireless and mobile security/privacy

This list is not exhaustive. Papers without a clear application to security or privacy may be rejected without full review.

## Systematization of Knowledge (SoK) Papers

We also solicit SoK papers that evaluate, systematize, and contextualize existing knowledge, providing important new viewpoints, challenging long-held beliefs, or presenting convincing taxonomies. Survey papers without such insights are not appropriate.

*   Submissions should be prefixed with "**SoK:**" in the title and indicate SoK status on the submission form.
*   Reviewed by the full PC and held to the same standards as traditional research papers.

## Submission Deadlines & Decisions

**First Deadline:**

*   Paper submission deadline: **June 6, 2024**
*   Early-reject notification: **July 22, 2024**
*   Rebuttal period (interactive): August 19 - August 30, 2024
*   Rebuttal text due: August 26, 2024
*   Acceptance notification: **September 9, 2024**
*   Camera-ready deadline: **October 18, 2024**

**Second Deadline:**

*   Paper submission deadline: **November 14, 2024**
*   Early-reject notification: **January 20, 2025**
*   Rebuttal period (interactive): February 17 - February 28, 2025
*   Rebuttal text due: February 24, 2025
*   Acceptance notification: **March 10, 2025**
*   Camera-ready deadline: **April 18, 2025**

## Public Meta-Reviews

Accepted papers will include a meta-review (< 500 words) listing acceptance reasons and PC concerns. Authors can provide a response (< 500 words). A shepherd will remove concerns if addressed by revisions.

## Symposium Event Changes

Each accepted paper will have:

*   A short talk presentation (e.g., 5-7 minutes).
*   A poster presentation immediately following the talk session.
*   All accepted papers are required to present both.

## Rebuttal Period

Papers in the second round will have an interactive rebuttal period with reviewers via HotCRP's anonymous communication feature. Focus on factual errors and concrete questions. New research results can be discussed if they clarify open questions.

## Resubmission of Rejected Papers

Rejected papers must wait one year before resubmission to IEEE S&P. Rejected papers are eligible for submission according to the following table:

| 2024 deadlines | Reject decision | Eligible 2025 deadlines |
|---|---|---|
| First 2024 (April 13, 2023) | Any | Either 2025 deadline |
| Second 2024 (August 3, 2023) | Any | Either 2025 deadline |
| Third 2024 (Dec 6, 2023) | Any | Second deadline (Nov 14, 2024) |

## Instructions for Paper Submission

*   All submissions must be original work; document any overlap with previously published or simultaneously submitted papers. Failure to do so may result in rejection.
*   Simultaneous submission to another venue with proceedings or a journal is not allowed.

### Anonymous Submission

*   Papers must be submitted for anonymous review: no author names or affiliations on the title page, and authors should avoid revealing their identity in the text.
*   Cite own work in the third person without identifying yourself. Blind references if necessary.
*   Papers not properly anonymized may be rejected without review.

Authors may give talks, post preprints to repositories (e.g., arXiv), and disclose vulnerabilities during submission. Contact PC chairs for exceptions.

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors must identify all potential conflicts of interest with PC members during submission. A conflict exists if:

*   The PC member is a co-author.
*   The PC member has been a co-worker in the same company or university within the past two years.
*   The PC member has been a collaborator within the past two years.
*   The PC member is or was the author’s primary thesis advisor.
*   The author is or was the PC member’s primary thesis advisor.
*   The PC member is a relative or close personal friend.

Explain any other conflicts to the PC chairs. Incorrect or incomplete conflict of interest information may lead to immediate rejection.

## Research Ethics Committee (REC)

Papers flagged by reviewers may be checked by the REC. Authors are encouraged to review the Menlo Report for ethical guidelines.

### Ethical Considerations for Vulnerability Disclosure

*   When identifying vulnerabilities, avoid gratuitous harm and protect users. Disclose to vendors and stakeholders.
*   A disclosure window of **45 to 90 days** ahead of publication is recommended.
*   Submitters must discuss steps taken or planned to address vulnerabilities. Full CVE identifiers should not be included in review submissions.

### Ethical Considerations for Human Subjects Research

*   Disclose IRB approval or waiver status if applicable.
*   Discuss steps taken to ensure ethical treatment of participants.
*   If dealing with personal identifiable information (PII) or sensitive data, detail steps taken to mitigate harms.

Papers raising significant ethical/legal concerns may be rejected.

## Financial and Non-financial Competing Interests

Authors must declare any competing interests in the camera-ready versions of their papers.

## Page Limit and Formatting

*   Submitted papers: up to **13 pages of text** + up to **5 pages for references and appendices** (total **18 pages**).
*   All text and figures past page 13 must be clearly marked as part of the appendix.
*   Final camera-ready paper: no more than 18 pages (PC chairs may allow more).
*   Papers must be formatted for **US letter** size paper.
*   **All submissions must use the IEEE “compsoc” conference proceedings template.** Use `IEEEtran.cls` version 1.8b with options "conference,compsoc.".
*   Papers not using the correct template, modifying margins, font, or line spacing, or using egregious space scrunching are subject to rejection without review.

## Withdrawing Policy

A paper can be withdrawn at any point before reviews are sent to authors. After reviews are sent, withdrawal is not permitted.

## Authorship Policy

Changes to authorship are not permitted after submission. Changes to affiliation after acceptance require PC chairs approval.

## Conference Submission Server

Submissions must be in Portable Document Format (.pdf).

*   First deadline server: [https://cycle1.sp2025.ieee-security.org/](https://cycle1.sp2025.ieee-security.org/)
*   Second deadline server: [https://cycle2.sp2025.ieee-security.org/](https://cycle2.sp2025.ieee-security.org/)

## Publication and Presentation

Authors are responsible for obtaining publication clearances. One author must register and present the paper at the conference.

## Organizing Committee Highlights

*   **General Chair:** Marina Blanton
*   **Program Chairs:** William Enck, Cristina Nita-Rotaru
*   **Treasurer:** Adwait Nadkarni
*   **Workshops Chairs:** Ziming Zhao, Gang Wang
*   **Short Talks Chair:** Bradley Reaves
*   **Posters Chair:** Kassem Fawaz

# Call For Papers

The **37th ACM Symposium on Parallelism in Algorithms and Architectures (SPAA ’25)** will run from **July 28—August 1, 2025**, in **Portland, Oregon**.

SPAA ’25 is sponsored by the ACM Special Interest Groups on Algorithms and Computation Theory (SIGACT) and Computer Architecture (SIGARCH) and organized in cooperation with the European Association for Theoretical Computer Science (EATCS).

## Submission Site

Papers will be submitted through HotCRP on the [submission site](https://spaa25.hotcrp.com).

## Topics of Interest

Submissions are sought in all areas of parallel and distributed computing, including algorithms, data structures, computational models, complexity theory, architectures, performance engineering, languages, runtime systems, compilers, programming systems, and networking systems. Papers that are purely theoretical, purely experimental, or contain both theory and experiments are welcome.

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Parallel and Distributed Algorithms
*   Parallel, Concurrent, and Distributed Data Structures
*   Models for Parallel and Distributed Computing
*   Parallel and Distributed Architectures
*   Parallel Programming Languages
*   System Software for Parallel and Concurrent Programming (including but not limited to Runtime, Compilers, and Tools)
*   Parallel Programming Frameworks and Domain-Specific Languages
*   Management of Massive Data Sets
*   Transactional Memory Hardware and Software
*   Supercomputer Architecture and Computing
*   Routing and Information Dissemination
*   Peer-to-Peer Systems
*   Mobile, Ad-Hoc, and Sensor Networks
*   Synergy of Parallelism in Algorithms, Programming and Architecture
*   Memory or I/O-efficient algorithms
*   Parallel Complexity Theory
*   Green Computing & Power-Efficient Architectures
*   Instruction Level Parallelism and VLSI
*   Scheduling Algorithms for Parallel Machines
*   Parallelism in Quantum Computing

## Submission Guidelines

### Paper Types

*   **Regular Papers:** Must report on original research that has not been previously or concurrently published.
    *   Maximum **20 pages** of text (excluding bibliography).
    *   Format: ACM “acmsmall” format using the `acmart` LaTeX class. This is a single-column page layout with a **10 pt font** and **12 pt line spacing**. The main text block should be **5.478 inches (13.91 cm) wide** and **7.884 inches (20.03 cm) tall**.
    *   Supplementary material is allowed, but reviewers are not obligated to read it.
*   **Brief Announcements:** Suitable for work in progress, tools/libraries, challenge problems, corrections, or smaller results.
    *   Maximum **six single-column pages** (excluding bibliography).

### Theory vs. Experiments

Submissions must be categorized as:

*   **A. Theory** (main contributions are theoretical)
*   **B. Experiments** (main contributions are experimental)
*   **C. Theory and Experiments** (main contributions are a mix of theory and experiments)

Please indicate the category during the submission process.

### Formatting

Submissions must use the final ACM “acmsmall” format from [https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template](https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template). More details are at [https://spaa.acm.org/submission-guidelines/](https://spaa.acm.org/submission-guidelines/).

## Review Process

SPAA 2025 will employ a **lightweight double-blind review process**.

*   Submissions should omit authors’ names, affiliations, and contact information.
*   References to prior work by the authors should be made in the third person.
*   Any supplemental materials should also be anonymized.
*   Authors are free to disseminate their ideas or draft versions of the paper (e.g., via arXiv or talks).
*   Reviewers will be asked to refrain from actively looking for the identity of the authors via web search.

## Conflict of Interest Policy

Authors must register their conflicts with PC members at the submission site. Conflicts include:

*   Academic advisor or advisee (no time limit)
*   Postdoctoral mentor or mentee (no time limit)
*   Collaborators within the past three years (joint research, development, paper, or funding)
*   Members of the same institution within the past 3 years
*   Family members or close friends
*   Someone involved in an alleged incident of harassment
*   Anyone whose relationship would prevent objectivity

False declarations risk rejection. Contact the program chair for clarification or unlisted valid reasons for conflict.

# SPIRE 2025: Call for Papers

The 32nd International Symposium on String Processing and Information Retrieval (SPIRE 2025) will be held in **London, UK, from September 08 - 11, 2025**.

## Scope

SPIRE 2025 covers research in all aspects of string processing, information retrieval, computational biology, and related applications. Typical topics of interest include (but are not limited to):

*   **String Processing:** string pattern matching, text indexing, data structures for string processing, text compression, compressed data structures, compressed string processing, text mining, 2D pattern matching, automata based string processing, combinatorics on words.
*   **Computational Biology:** algorithms for DNA sequencing, assembly, alignments, read error correction, metagenomics, transcriptomics, gene and regulatory element recognition, motif finding, pangenomics, variants discovery, phylogenetics, genome rearrangements.
*   **Information Retrieval:** Retrieval models and ranking. Theoretical models and foundations of IR. Efficiency and scalability topics in IR. Knowledge acquisition in IR. Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing for IR. Knowledge representation and reasoning for IR. User-centric aspects of IR. IR Evaluation. Fairness, accountability, transparency in IR. Domain-specific IR applications. Web search.

## Submissions

SPIRE 2025 invites submissions in two categories:

*   **Long papers:** Up to 12 pages, excluding references and optional appendices.
*   **Short papers:** Up to 6 pages, excluding references and optional appendices.

Papers should be submitted electronically via EasyChair via the following link: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spire2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=spire2025)

As in past editions, the proceedings of SPIRE 2025 will be published by Springer in the Lecture Notes in Computer Science (LNCS) series. The use of LNCS templates is mandatory. Suitable templates are available at the Springer Website and on Overleaf. Do not change the margin size or the font, do not make a separate title page, etc.: use the LNCS style file as given.

Simultaneous submissions to other conferences with published proceedings is not permitted.

At least one author per accepted paper is expected to register for the conference and present the paper. The conference will be in-person, with online presentations only in special cases (e.g., authors with travel difficulties).

# IFAC Joint Conference SSSC 2025 - TDS 2025 - COSY 2025: Call for Papers

The 9th Symposium on System Structure and Control (SSSC 2025), 19th Workshop on Time Delay Systems (TDS 2025), and 2nd Workshop on Control of Complex Systems (COSY 2025) will be held jointly in **Gif-sur-Yvette, France**, from **June 30th to July 2nd, 2025**, at **CentraleSupélec**.

## Aims and Scope

The aim of this joint event is to gather academics and professionals with a particular interest in system structure, control, linear and nonlinear system theory. It offers a forum to discuss current research developments, open problems, and to establish scientific networks focusing on the mathematical structure of systems and its impact on control systems design and performance.

## Submission Policy

*   All papers must be submitted through the conference submission website ([https://ifac.papercept.net/conferences/scripts/start.pl](https://ifac.papercept.net/conferences/scripts/start.pl)).
*   Contributions can be submitted as either an **extended abstract (2 pages)** or a **full paper (minimum 4 and maximum 8 pages initial submission, 6 pages final submission)**, in A4 size and PDF format.
*   Accepted papers will be published in IFAC Papers on-line. Abstract submissions will NOT be published in IFAC Papers on-line but will be included in the conference preprints.
*   A regular registration by an Author allows the upload of up to 2 accepted papers. A reduced registration for Students/Retirees allows the upload of up to one accepted paper.
*   All submitted material must be original and not under review elsewhere.

*   **Call for Invited Sessions:** Invited sessions consist of 5-6 papers with a unifying theme. Proposals must describe motivation and relevance.

## Research Track

SYSTOR accepts both full-length and short papers. A short paper is intended for an idea that can be described and evaluated in fewer pages; the goal of the short paper is not for preliminary work or workshop-style position papers.

A good SYSTOR paper should present a novel, compelling solution to a well-motivated problem. The evaluation should demonstrate the strengths and weaknesses of the solution in settings that are as realistic as possible, including test applications workloads, system parameters, and assumed constraints. Authors should clearly describe their contribution in the context of prior work, and draw meaningful conclusions from their work.

The program committee also encourages submissions that describe lessons learned from operational (especially large-scale) system deployments. Such submissions are expected to include sufficient details of the system, its design goals, and the methods used for evaluating whether these goals were met.

The program committee will value submissions accompanied by supplemental material such as traces and open-source code that can help reproduce the reported results, and advance additional research in the field.

A small set of outstanding papers will be forwarded to a suitable journal, such as ACM journal Transactions on Storage (TOS) or Transactions on Computer Systems (TOCS), for a fast-tracked review process for an expanded version of the paper.

SYSTOR will enforce ACM’s plagiarism policy regarding copying and resubmitting prior work. Simultaneous submissions are not allowed: any work submitted to SYSTOR must not be under consideration for another workshop, conference, or journal.

AUTHORS TAKE NOTE: The official publication date is the earlier of either the first day of the conference or the date the proceedings are made available in the ACM Digital Library. This date may be up to two weeks before the first day of your conference. The official publication date affects the deadline for any patent filings related to published work.

## Formatting Instructions

Submissions must be printable PDF files. When creating your submission, you must use the sigplan proceedings template of ACM’s acmart Latex class, which is available on the official ACM site. Your main LaTeX file should have the following structure:

```latex
% use the base acmart.cls

% use the sigplan proceeding template with the default 10 pt fonts

% nonacm option removes ACM-related text in the submission. 
\documentclass[sigplan,nonacm]{acmart}

% enable page numbers
\settopmatter{printfolios=true}
\begin{document}

\title{…}

\begin{abstract}

…

\maketitle % should come after the abstract

% Add the paper content here

```

A paper submitted to SYSTOR can be submitted simultaneously to Arxiv, with some changes. We would like the authors to make an honest effort to preserve anonymity. The authors of a SYSTOR submission are encouraged to associate a source code repo with their submission, but this repo must be completely anonymized. ## Camera-Ready Submission

Kindly review and finalize the title of your submission and the author list (including their order). Please use the “edit” version on the HotCRP submission site to make updates. Note the deadline for completing this action is prior to the Camera-ready date.

This information is needed to generate ACM copyright forms, which you need to sign *before* submitting your final camera-ready version. After completing the rights management form, you will be sent rights text and DOI info to add to the paper before the final PDF is generated and submitted.

**Camera-Ready Submission Instructions**

These instructions apply to papers, short papers, and posters (extended abstracts). Contact proceeding publication chair Surbhi Palande for questions.

When authors submit their eRights forms to ACM, they receive confirmation messages that include the appropriate copyright text & DOI (document identifier) for their papers. Once complete, the camera-ready paper should be submitted through HotCRP.

*   Be sure that there are no bad page or column breaks, meaning no widows (last line of a paragraph at the top of a column). Section and subsection headings should remain with at least 2 lines of body text when near the end of a page or column.
*   Include the DOI in your paper that you received from ACM (use \acmDOI{####}) and update the ISBN data: \acmISBN{979-8-4007-1181-7}
*   The camera-ready version must include the updated copyright text you received from ACM. If you did not see an email referring to the ACM right management form, please check your SPAM folders. If this form is not received for a paper before the deadline, then that paper cannot be included in the proceedings.

Notes on adding copyright text:

*   Additionally note that the author can access the correct copyright under their paper edit submission link. At the top there is ‘Final version preparation’, which include the copyright text message. There is also a ‘Latex Instruction’ (collapsed) section with exact LaTeX instructions.
*   You should use the default class without font size and without the anonymous flag – `\documentclass[sigconf]{acmart,10pt}` – this would set 10pt font. Page count remains unchanged.
*   Alongside the camera-ready PDF, you will be required to *submit the source files* for your paper, including ALL files which were used to create the final output (PDF), be they Word, LaTeX, image files, etc. This is mandatory.

The following template contains the required settings: [Concise-Paper-Template.zip](https://www.systor.org/2024/wp-content/uploads/sites/7/2024/08/SYSTOR-2024-Concise-Paper-Template.zip)

# Call for Papers: TACAS 2025

The 31st International Conference on Tools and Algorithms for the Construction and Analysis of Systems (TACAS 2025) is a premier forum for researchers, developers, and users interested in rigorously based tools and algorithms for the construction and analysis of systems. TACAS aims to bridge the gaps between different communities with this common interest and to support them in their quest to improve the utility, reliability, flexibility, and efficiency of tools and algorithms for building systems.

Theoretical papers with clear relevance for tool construction and analysis, as well as tool descriptions and case studies with a conceptual message, are all encouraged.

## Topics of Interest

The topics covered by the conference include, but are not limited to:

*   Specification and verification techniques
*   Software and hardware verification
*   Analytical techniques for real-time, hybrid, or stochastic systems
*   Analytical techniques for safety, security, or dependability
*   SAT and SMT solving
*   Theorem proving
*   Model checking
*   Static and dynamic program analysis
*   Testing
*   Abstraction techniques for modeling and verification
*   Compositional and refinement-based methodologies
*   System construction and transformation techniques
*   Machine-learning techniques for synthesis and verification
*   Tool environments and tool architectures
*   Applications and case studies

## Submission Categories

TACAS accepts four types of submissions:

*   **Research Papers:** Identify and justify a principled advance to the theoretical foundations for the construction and analysis of systems. Where applicable, they are supported by experimental validation. Artifact evaluation for these papers is not mandatory but strongly encouraged. Authors are advised not to post their submissions on arXiv or similar repositories around the submission deadline.
*   **Case-Study Papers:** Full-length case-studies that describe the application of techniques developed by the community to a single problem or a set of problems of practical importance, preferably in a real-world setting. Artifact evaluation is not mandatory but strongly encouraged.
*   **Regular Tool Papers:** Full-length papers that describe a tool of interest to the community or a new version of a tool built using novel algorithmic and engineering techniques. These papers must describe tools of broad interest and utility. **All tool papers must undergo mandatory artifact evaluation.**
*   **Tool Demonstration Papers:** Short papers that demonstrate a new tool or the application of an existing tool on a significant and novel case-study. **Artifact evaluation is mandatory for these papers.**

## Paper Submission

*   **Submission Portal:** Papers must be submitted electronically in PDF format through the [Easychair author interface of TACAS 2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=tacas25).
*   **Formatting:** Submissions must follow the formatting guidelines of Springer’s LNCS (use the `llncs.cls` class).
*   **Review Process:**
    *   **Double-blind** reviewing applies to regular research papers. Authors must omit their names and institutions, refer to prior work in the third person, and avoid acknowledgments that might identify them.
    *   **Single-blind** reviewing applies to case study papers, regular tool papers, and tool-demonstration papers.
*   **Page Limits:**
    *   Regular research papers, case study papers, and regular tool papers: **16 pp** (excluding bibliography and appendices).
    *   Tool demonstration papers: **6 pp** (excluding bibliography and appendices).
*   **Appendices:** Additional material can be placed in a clearly marked appendix. Reviewers are not obliged to read appendices.
*   **Author Limit:** TACAS 2025 allows at most four submissions per author.
*   **Conflict of Interest:** Authors are required to declare their Conflict of Interest (COI) with TACAS 2025 PC members upon submission.

## Important Dates

All times are Anywhere on Earth (AoE) unless otherwise specified:

*   **Submission deadline for TACAS, FoSSaCS, FASE:** October 10, 2024
*   **TACAS mandatory artifact submission deadline:** October 24, 2024
*   **Rebuttal (ESOP, FoSSaCS, partially TACAS):** December 3–5, 2024
*   **Paper notification and TACAS mandatory artifact notification:** December 20, 2024
*   **ESOP, FASE, FoSSaCS artifact, TACAS voluntary artifact submission deadline:** January 9, 2025
*   **Paper final version:** January 30, 2025
*   **Artifact notification ESOP, FASE, FoSSaCS, TACAS (voluntary artifacts):** February 13, 2025
*   **Main Conference:** May 5–8, 2025

## Artifact Evaluation

*   **Mandatory:** For regular tool paper and tool demonstration paper submissions. Artifacts must be submitted by **October 24, 2024**. The outcome of the artifact evaluation will be considered in the paper’s acceptance decision.
*   **Voluntary:** For research paper and case study paper submissions. Authors can submit artifacts after paper acceptance (deadline: **January 9, 2025**). The outcome of the voluntary artifact evaluation will not alter the paper acceptance decision.
*   Details on artifacts and their evaluation criteria are available on the [artifacts page](https://tacas.info/artifacts-25.php).

## Publication

The proceedings will be published in the [Advanced Research in Computing and Software Science (ARCoSS)](https://link.springer.com/series/15194) subline of Springer’s LNCS series. The proceedings volumes will appear in gold open access, meaning published versions will be freely available online. Authors retain copyright.

## ETAPS 2025 Context

TACAS 2025 is held as part of the ETAPS 2025 joint conferences, which are organized by McMaster University in Hamilton, Canada.

# Call for Papers: TAP 2024

TAP 2024 is the **18th International Conference on Tests and Proofs**, scheduled to take place on **September 9–10, 2024**, in **Milan, Italy**. The conference is part of **FM 2024**.

## Scope

TAP promotes research in verification and formal methods that targets the interplay of static and dynamic analysis techniques with the ultimate goal of improving software and system dependability. Research in verification has seen an increase in heterogeneous techniques and a synergy between the traditionally distinct areas of dynamic and static analysis. There is growing awareness that dynamic techniques such as testing and static techniques such as proving are complementary rather than mutually exclusive. Notable examples that provide evidence for the potential of a combination of static and dynamic analysis are counterexample generation based on symbolic execution, the integration of SAT/SMT-solving in model checking, or the combination of predicate abstraction with exhaustive enumeration. The verification of systems based on machine learning spurs novel combinations of dynamic and static analyses, e.g., property verification of surrogate models that are generated through testing.

TAP’s scope encompasses many aspects of verification technology, including foundational work, tool development, and empirical research. Topics of interest center around the combination of static techniques such as proving and dynamic techniques such as testing.

## Invited Speakers

*   **Rosemary Monahan** (Maynooth University, Ireland)
*   **Rüdiger Ehlers** (TU Clausthal, Germany)

## Topics of Interest

Papers are solicited on, but not limited to, the following topics:

*   Verification and analysis techniques combining proofs and tests,
*   Static analysis of programs with the aid of dynamic techniques,
*   Deductive techniques supporting the automated generation of test vectors and oracles,
*   Deductive techniques supporting (novel) definitions of coverage criteria,
*   Specification inference by deductive or dynamic methods,
*   Testing and runtime analysis of formal specifications,
*   Search-based techniques for proving and testing,
*   Testing and Verification of systems based on machine learning,
*   Verification of verification tools and environments,
*   Applications of test and proof techniques in new domains,
*   Combined approaches of test and proof in the context of formal certifications (Common Criteria, CENELEC, …),
*   Case studies, tool and framework descriptions, and experience reports

## Submission and Proceedings

Accepted submissions will be published in **Springer’s LNCS series**.

Please check the [submission page](/2024/submission.html) for detailed instructions for preparing your submission.

# TechDebt 2025: Call for Papers

The International Conference on Technical Debt (TechDebt) 2025, the 8th edition of the series, will be held in **Ottawa, Ontario, Canada**, from **April 27-28, 2025**. TechDebt 2025 is co-located with the 47th International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE 2025).

## About TechDebt

TechDebt is the premier conference dedicated to managing technical debt (TD), bringing together leading software engineering researchers, practitioners, educators, and tool developers. It serves as a platform to discuss approaches for managing various types of TD, share experiences and best practices, and identify key challenges for industry and academia.

## Tracks

*   [**Industry Track**](https://conf.researchr.org/track/TechDebt-2025/TechDebt-2025-industry-track)
*   [**Technical Papers**](https://conf.researchr.org/track/TechDebt-2025/TechDebt-2025-main)
*   [**Journal First**](https://conf.researchr.org/track/TechDebt-2025/TechDebt-2025-journal-first)

## Topics of Interest

The conference warmly invites research and practical contributions. Topics include, but are not limited to:

*   **Investigations on Specific Technical Debt Types:** Specific technical debt types (e.g., test debt, build debt, architectural debt), less studied kinds of technical debt (e.g., requirement, documentation, security debt), other types of debt (e.g., social debt, process debt), and debt in specific domains (e.g., AI-based systems, mobile applications).
*   **Case Studies and Practical Experiences:** Case studies on successful and unsuccessful technical debt management practices, remediation in real-world projects, industry experiences, and empirical evidence on the effectiveness of TD management tools and approaches.
*   **Tools and Approaches for Managing Technical Debt:** Tools, demos, and libraries for TD identification, assessment, and management; methods and frameworks for monitoring and managing TD; decision frameworks for prioritizing debt; estimation of TD principal and interest; and quality assurance practices.
*   **Human and Organizational Factors:** Human factors in managing TD (e.g., team dynamics, communication challenges), stakeholder perspectives, and the impact of organizational culture.
*   **Emerging Trends in Technical Debt Research:** Use of AI/ML for TD management, software visualization techniques, TD for AI-driven systems and mobile applications, and the role of software economics.
*   **Position and Vision Papers:** Novel perspectives, new conceptual frameworks, and metrics for studying TD.

## Paper Categories

*   **Research Papers:** (up to 10 pages + 2 pages for references) - Innovative and significant original research.
*   **Experience Papers:** (up to 10 pages + 2 pages for references) - Industrial experiences, case studies, challenges, and solutions.
*   **Short Papers:** (up to 5 pages + 2 pages for references) - Early stage research, new ideas, visions, reflections, or tools.

All submissions must be in PDF and adhere to the IEEE conference proceedings template.

## Review Process

Submissions undergo a rigorous review by at least three program committee members, evaluated on novelty, rigor, relevance, verifiability, and presentation. TechDebt 2025 uses a **doubly anonymous reviewing model**. Submissions that do not comply with anonymity requirements may be desk-rejected.

*   **Abstract deadline:** November 8, 2024
*   **Paper deadline:** November 15, 2024

# Call for Participation: TEI '26

We invite paper submissions from a wide range of perspectives: technical, applied, empirical, theoretical, philosophical, conceptual, and artistic. We welcome contributions from fields including but not limited to: tangible interaction design, embodied interaction design, embedded computing, digital fabrication, hybrid craft, e-textiles, wearables, haptics, robotics, smart cities, smart materials, and sustainability.

## Theme: 'Tide + Tied'

As this year's theme is 'Tide + Tied', we invite submissions that explore interdisciplinary knowledge, bridging the physical and digital, technology and humanity, resurgence and convergence, and beyond. We expect submissions to be clearly framed within the rapidly developing tangible, embedded, and embodied interaction field. Works framed as research through design and more technical contributions are particularly welcome.

## Contribution Types

Authors are invited to submit high-quality papers that contribute to advancing this rapidly developing field. Accepted submissions of all contribution types will be included as papers in the conference proceedings, which will be available in the ACM Digital Library.

*   **Artifact:** Research artifacts that advance the state of the art in Tangible, Embedded and Embodied Interaction.
*   **Method:** Tools, approaches and techniques that enable researchers, technologists, designers and practitioners to study, research and work in Tangible, Embedded and Embodied Interaction.
*   **Theory:** Explorations, extensions, refutations, instantiations and other developments of and to the theories pertaining to Tangible, Embedded and Embodied Interaction.
*   **Empirical:** Studies and data that add to our understanding of Tangible, Embedded and Embodied Interaction.

## Paper Length

Authors are encouraged to submit a paper with a length proportional to its contribution. While there is no maximum or minimum length for papers, the length of typical submissions is expected to be approximately **7,000–8,000 words** excluding references, figure/table captions, and appendices. Papers should be succinct but thorough in presenting the work. Shorter, more focused papers are encouraged and will be reviewed like any other paper.

## Important Dates

*   **Abstract Deadline:** July 31, 2025, AoE
*   **Full Submission Deadline:** August 7, 2025, AoE
*   **Video and Supplementary Material Deadline:** August 14, 2025, AoE
*   **Notification of Conditional Acceptance:** October 15, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Deadline:** November 20, 2025
*   **TEI 2026 Conference:** March 8-11, 2025

## Submission Guidelines

*   **ACM Format Requirements:** TEI 2026 uses the new ACM workflow TAPS for submission templates and published papers. TAPS requires the use of a simplified one-column template for submission, while the final two-column paper will be rendered for publication after acceptance. We strongly recommend using the LaTeX templates rather than Word. Papers do not have a page limit. All relevant information, including submission templates in Word and LaTeX, can be found here: [https://www.acm.org/publications/authors/submissions](https://www.acm.org/publications/authors/submissions)
*   **Authorship Policy:** Your submission must be original and cannot have been published or be under concurrent review elsewhere. Avoid using text generated by AI-tools; if used, disclose in the acknowledgements. Refer to the [ACM policy on authorship](https://www.acm.org/publications/policies/new-acm-policy-on-authorship).
*   **Anonymization Policy:** All papers must be anonymized for review. Author and affiliation sections must be left blank. Remove identifying information from the document's metadata and the acknowledgements section. Citations to previous work should be left unanonymized, but authors are encouraged to cite their own work in the third person.
*   **Submission:** All abstracts and full papers must be submitted electronically via the Precision Conference (PCS) website before their respective deadlines. Authors must select their preferred presentation format (talk, demo, poster).

## Review Process

Each paper will be assigned a primary AC (1AC) and a secondary AC (2AC). The 1AC will find two external reviewers. Each paper will receive 3 detailed reviews. The 1AC will write a meta-review, and then present a recommendation to the Program Chairs. Program Chairs will make the final decision.

## After Acceptance

Authors of accepted papers must present their work at the conference. Accepted papers will be included in the Proceedings of TEI 2026 and available in the ACM Digital Library. Authors are responsible for obtaining permissions for licensed content and images, and must grant permission to record/stream their presentations.

## Policy on Use of Large Language Models

Text and images generated from a large-scale language model (LLM) must be clearly marked where such tools are used for purposes beyond editing the author's own text. Disclose LLM use in the acknowledgements section. Submissions with undisclosed LLM use may be desk-rejected.

## Program Chairs

Sara Nabil, HyunJoo Oh, Elisa Rubegni
For further questions, please contact the Paper chairs at [program_chairs2026@tei.acm.org](mailto:program_chairs2026@tei.acm.org).

# Call for Papers - TrustCom 2024

As computer systems, communication networks, and artificial intelligence (AI) rapidly develop and increase in complexity, user expectations for trust, security, and privacy have grown considerably. This presents a significant challenge, as traditional security technologies may struggle to meet evolving demands in open, dynamic, heterogeneous, mobile, wireless, and distributed computing environments. # UCNC 2025: Call for Papers

The 22nd International Conference on Unconventional Computation and Natural Computation (UCNC 2025) will be held from **September 1-5, 2025**, at the **Université Côte d'Azur, Valrose Campus, Nice, France**.

The UCNC series is a forum bringing together scientists from many different backgrounds who are united in their interest in novel forms of computation, human-designed computation inspired by nature, and computational aspects of natural processes.

## Aims and Scope

Papers and poster presentations are sought in all areas relating to unconventional computation and natural computation. Both theoretical and experimental papers are welcome.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Molecular computing
*   Quantum computing
*   Optical computing
*   Chaos computing
*   Physarum computing
*   Collision-based computing
*   Self-assembling and self-organizing systems
*   Super-Turing computation
*   Cellular automata
*   Neural computation
*   Evolutionary computation
*   Swarm intelligence
*   Ant algorithms
*   Artificial immune systems
*   Artificial life
*   Membrane computing
*   Amorphous computing
*   Computational systems biology
*   Computational neuroscience
*   Synthetic biology
*   Cellular (in-vivo) computing

## Paper Categories

There are four submission categories:

*   **Regular papers:** These contain original research not yet communicated to other conferences or journals. Regular papers should not exceed **15 pages**.
*   **Short papers:** These are intended for communicating fresh new original research which is not yet complete or still needs some development. Short papers should not exceed **6 pages**.
*   **Late-breaking abstracts:** These are informal presentations of new research and/or research direction proposals, as well as presentations of research that has already been presented at other conferences, with the purpose of further dissemination of results or research directions. They should not exceed **3 pages**.
*   **Posters:** Posters should be one page in A0 format (plus 1 page abstract).

*Only accepted regular and short papers will appear in the LNCS proceedings. All paper categories will go through a review process suitable for the given category.* 

## Author Guidelines

Submitted papers must describe work not previously published, and they must neither be accepted nor under review in a journal or at another conference with refereed proceedings.

### Paper Preparation

Authors are required to submit their manuscripts electronically in PDF using the **LNCS style**. Authors using LaTeX can download the needed macros at the [Springer-Verlag site](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/editor-guidelines-for-springer-proceedings).

Papers should respect the page limits announced above; full proofs may appear in a clearly marked technical appendix which can be read by the reviewers.

The submission process is completely managed via the EasyChair website. Please use the following submission URL: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ucnc2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ucnc2025)

### Preparing the Final Version for the Proceedings

The final versions of accepted papers must be formatted in LaTeX using Springer-Verlag's Lecture Notes style.

*   For regular papers, authors may use up to **16 pages** including references, title page and acknowledgements.
*   For short papers, authors may use up to **6 pages** including references, title page and acknowledgements.

Please also consult the [Instructions for Authors](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/editor-guidelines-for-springer-proceedings) provided by Springer.

The final version should be uploaded on the Easychair website in zipped format containing the final source files, a final PDF file, and a signed license-to-publish agreement.

> *Important*: At least one author of each accepted paper, late-breaking abstract and poster has to register, attend the conference and present the work.

## Important Dates

**Conference:** September 1-5, 2025

**Regular & Short Papers Deadlines:**

*   **Submission:** May 15th, 2025
*   **Notification:** June 15th, 2025
*   **Camera Ready:** July 8th, 2025

**Late-Breaking Abstracts & Posters Deadlines:**

*   **Submission:** May 15th, 2025
*   **Notification:** June 1st, 2025

## Special Issue

A special issue of the international journal Natural Computing will be organized after the conference containing a selection of articles presented at the conference. These will be substantially extended versions of the papers and will undergo an independent peer review process.

The Nineteenth International Conference on Mobile Ubiquitous Computing, Systems, Services and Technologies (UBICOMM 2025) will take place from **September 28, 2025 to October 02, 2025 in Lisbon, Portugal**.
